abstracts.cdata!:
The project was generally successful in
            achieving its planned outcome of strengthening national
            capacity to confront food security and poverty in
            Mozambique, despite low disbursement levels due to
            disappointing evolution of the formal training component of
            the project. Importantly, the project supported analysis and
            the foundation of key policies and strategies on food
            security and poverty, and built institutional and technical
            capacity in these areas. Both World Bank and Borrower
            performance were satisfactory on the whole. Key lessons
            included the following: Project simplicity, clear
            objectives, and flexible design are important, particularly
            where there are capacity constraints and rapid change.
            Government ownership is vital. Balancing timely delivery of
            outputs and in depth research on one hand and ensuring that
            nationals learn from the experience on the other, depend
            both on careful supervision and the implementing
            agency's commitment to capacity building. Capacity
            building projects should be sustained in order to ensure
            sustainability of outcome. Short-term and on-the-job
            training may be more appropriate for government officials
            than longer-term training abroad (advanced degree programs).
            The effectiveness of technical assistance programs depends
            on both the quality of the program and the relationships
            between the technical advisors and their counterparts,
            Borrower officials.
